repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Health System Strengthening and
            Response to Epidemiological Emergencies Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Strengthening and Response to Epidemiological Emergencies
            Project for Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: emergency projects like this one need to be kept
            simple, flexible and focused on solving the problem.
            Therefore the Bank needs to ensure that procurement policies
            can be used flexibly, and that decisions can be made
            efficiently. This operation had some problems with timing.
            The project was able to compensate for the time lost,
            because of its focus on building long-term capacity for
            surveillance and prevention. The monitoring and results
            framework was succinct and appropriate for the emergency
            operation and covered all development objectives. The
            project design will have benefitted from including a
            thorough economic analysis, as well as an impact analysis
            with data on treatment, service utilization, and
            effectiveness of the surveillance system. The results
            framework reflects mostly outputs from project activities,
            and quantitative data on the status and effectiveness of the
            surveillance system was not routinely available for
            inclusion in this report. This lesson should be taken into
            account for the design of similar projects, where one of the
            main goals is to build surveillance capacity.

16628186.projn:
NI-Health System Strengthening And Response
            To Epidemiological Eme -- P112906

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Health Systems Strengthening
            and Response to Epidemiological Emergencies Project : Restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed request from the Government
            of Nicaragua dated March 23, 2011, includes a reallocation
            of the Grant proceeds to cover the overdraft of 150,488
            (SDR) in Category 1 (Goods and Consultants services for
            Part A of the project), reducing funds from Category 2
            (Goods and Consultants services and Non Consultants services
            for Part B of the Project), and Category 3 (Consultant
            services for Part C of the project). The Government proposed
            this reallocation due to a substantial reduction in the
            amount of grant proceeds available for project activities
            due to a difference in exchange rates of the Special Drawing
            Rights (SDR). Despite this situation, the Government has
            carried out the activities established under the MINSA-PAHO Agreement.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Health System Strengthening and
            Response to Epidemiological Emergencies Project : emergency
            project paper

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health System
            Strengthening and Response to Epidemiological Emergencies
            Project is to strengthen the capacity of the Republic of
            Nicaragua's health system to support the control of the
            spread and the effects of NHlNl Human Influenza through
            prevention, monitoring, and treatment of affected
            populations, with special attention to high risk groups. The
            grant will help finance the costs associated with the
            Government's effort to monitor, control, and reduce the
            number of fatalities and the risk of contraction of the
            A/HlNl Human Influenza, which has resulted in 2,152
            confirmed cases of the A/HlN1 Human Influenza registered as
            of October 30, 2009, and eighteen deaths reported. Given
            that epidemiologists expect a second wave of the influenza
            to hit Central America beginning in the Fall, the Government
            of Nicaragua (GoN) has requested Bank support in
            strengthening its capacity to manage the spread of the virus
            (and other influenza viruses as well). The project will
            assist Nicaragua in improving its epidemiological
            surveillance system and providing medicines to treat
            infected individuals, with special attention to high risk groups.
